source.title: Gospel and Word of the Day - 13 December 2025

celebrations.name: Saint Lucy of Syracuse, Virgin and Martyr

readings.heading: A reading from the Book of Sirach
lines: Also there arose Elijah the prophet as fire,
And his word burned like a torch:
Who brought a famine upon them,
And by his zeal made them few in number.
By the word of the Lord he shut up the heaven:
Thrice did he thus bring down fire.
How was you glorified, O Elijah, in your wondrous deeds!
And who shall glory like to you?
Who was taken up in a tempest of fire,
In a chariot of fiery horses:
Who was recorded for reproofs in their seasons,
To pacify anger, before it brake forth into wrath;
To turn the heart of the father to the son,
And to restore the tribes of Jacob.
Blessed are those who saw you,
And those who have been beautified with love;
For we also shall surely live.

readings.heading: From the Gospel according to Matthew
lines: As they were coming down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, saying,
“Don’t tell anyone what you saw, until the Son of Man has risen from the dead.”
His disciples asked him, saying, “Then why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?”
Jesus answered them,
“Elijah indeed comes first, and will restore all things,
but I tell you that Elijah has come already, and they didn’t recognize him, but did to him whatever they wanted to. Even so the Son of Man will also suffer by them.”
Then the disciples understood that he spoke to them of John the Baptizer.

marginalia.text: Elijah rendered as combustion: prophet = ignition; speech = heat.
Power over scarcity and sky; judgment enacted by withdrawal and fire.
Exit is not death but transport; fire frames both ministry and departure.
Stored as a future instrument: reproof timed to avert wrath.
Restoration defined as relational reversal (fathers/sons) and political repair (tribes).
Beatitude shifts from Elijah’s glory to witnesses’ beautification; life promised by proximity.
Theophany sealed under a resurrection embargo; disclosure is scheduled, not denied.
Scribes’ sequence problem: Elijah first, then kingdom.
Two claims held together: Elijah “will restore” and “has come” unrecognized—restoration arrives in misrecognition and violence.
Typology tightened: what is done to the forerunner prefigures what will be done to the Son of Man.
Identification collapses the expectation: Elijah = John, not a returned fire-chariot.

reading.text: Elijah is described as fire; the text treats prophetic speech as an element that consumes.
The prophet’s authority is cosmic (heaven shut) and punitive (famine, descending fire) but explicitly derivative: “by the word of the Lord.”
Elijah’s translation in fire becomes part of his profile, not merely an ending.
Elijah is positioned as an eschatological lever: reproof, anger-pacification, household reconciliation, tribal restoration.

gospel.text: Jesus controls testimony: the vision’s meaning is unintelligible apart from resurrection.
The Elijah expectation is affirmed and reinterpreted: the restoring figure came as one who could be ignored and harmed; restoration is not triumphal.
John’s fate becomes the interpretive key and the template for the Son of Man’s suffering.

commentary.synthesis: Sirach casts Elijah as fiery judgment and future restoration; Matthew relocates that role into John the Baptizer, showing restoration arriving under concealment, misrecognition, and suffering, with revelation deferred until resurrection.
